Congratulations on getting your permit! You're all set for an amazing adventure on the High Sierra Trail.

And wow, you're really getting in some great hiking practice with your weekly Grizzly Peak hikes! Those views of the Bay Area must be stunning.

Now, about altitude sickness: it's a serious concern when hiking at high elevations, and it's essential to know how to recognize and manage the symptoms. Here are some tips to help you deal with potential altitude sickness:

**Recognize the Symptoms:**

* Headache
* Fatigue
* Nausea and vomiting
* Dizziness or lightheadedness
* Shortness of breath
* Loss of appetite
* Insomnia

**Prevention is Key:**

* Acclimatize gradually: Take your time ascending to higher elevations. Spend a few days at lower elevations (around 8,000-9,000 ft) before heading higher.
* Hydrate: Drink plenty of water to stay hydrated, especially at higher elevations.
* Eat nutritious food: Fuel your body with balanced meals and snacks.
* Avoid overexertion: Take regular breaks and pace yourself.

**Managing Symptoms:**

* If you experience mild symptoms, rest and hydrate. If symptoms persist or worsen, descend to a lower elevation.
* Take medication: Diamox (acetazolamide) can help alleviate symptoms, but it's essential to consult with a doctor before taking it.
* Monitor your body: Keep an eye on your symptoms and those of your hiking partners.

**Descend if Necessary:**

* If symptoms are severe or worsening, descend to a lower elevation (at least 1,000-2,000 ft) and rest.
* Don't try to push through severe altitude sickness, as it can be life-threatening.

**Additional Tips:**

* Be aware of your body's response to high elevation. If you've experienced altitude sickness before, take extra precautions.
* Hike with a partner or group, so you can monitor each other's symptoms.
* Bring a first-aid kit and know how to use the items in it.

Remember, it's always better to err on the side of caution when it comes to altitude sickness. If you're unsure about your symptoms or the severity of the situation, descend and seek medical attention.

Now, get ready for an incredible adventure on the High Sierra Trail!
